question:
A sequence of complex numbers $z_0,z_1,z_2,\ldots$ is defined by the rule \[
z_{n+1}=\frac{\ iz_n\ }{\overline{z}_n},
\]where $\overline{z}_n$ is the complex conjugate of $z_n$ and $i^2=-1$. Suppose that $|z_0|=1$ and $z_{2005}=1$. How many possible values are there for $z_0$?
answer:
Note that \[
z_{n+1}=\frac{iz_n}{\overline{z}_n}=\frac{iz_n^2}{z_n\overline{z}_n}=\frac{iz_n^2}{|z_n|^2}.
\]Since $|z_0|=1$, the sequence satisfies \[
z_1 = i z_0^2, \ z_2 = iz_1^2 = i\left(iz_0^2\right)^2 = -iz_0^4,
\]and, in general, when $k\ge 2$, \[
z_k = -iz_0^{2^k}.
\]Hence $z_0$ satisfies the equation $1 =-iz_0^{(2^{2005})}$, so $z_0^{(2^{2005})} = i.$ Because every nonzero complex number has $n$ distinct $n$th roots, this  equation has $2^{2005}$ solutions. So there are $\boxed{2^{2005}}$ possible values for $z_0$.
agents_response:
We start by evaluating $z_1$:

$z_1= \dfrac{i z_0}{\overline{z_0}}$

Because $|z_0|=1$, we have $|iz_0| = |z_0| = 1$ putting it in the above equation we have:

$z_1= \dfrac{i}{\overline{z_0}}$

Both the numerator and the denominator have the same modulus (namely 1), so their ratio also has modulus 1, i.e. $|z_1|=1$. The similar argument also applies to $z_2, z_3, z_4, \ldots, z_{2005}$. So $|z_j| = 1$ for all $j$. 

Notice that the complex numbers whose modulus equal to 1 are exactly the points on the unit circle in the complex plane.

Taking $n=2004$ we see that $z_{2005} = \dfrac{i}{\overline{z_{2004}}}$ and since $z_{2005} = 1$, we have ${\overline{z_{2004}}} = i$, on to the unit circle this means $z_{2004}$ should lie on the real axis. By convention, if $z_{2004}$ lies on the positive side of the real axis, then there should be 2 qualified $z_{2004}$, one is $z_{2004} = 1$ and the other one is $z_{2004} = -1$. If $z_{2004}$ lies on the negative side of the real axis, then there is no qualified $z_{2004}$.

We call $n_{2004}$ which denotes the number of times that the numbers $z_0, z_1, \ldots, z_{2004}$ move around the origin and $n_{2004}$ could be negative if the numbers move in the negative direction. By the rule of constructing $z_{n+1}$, we have $n_{2004} \bmod 2 = 0$ then $z_{2004} = 1$ and if $n_{2004} \bmod 2 = 1$ then $z_{2004} = -1$.

We want that $z_{2004}$ is on the positive side of the real axis, by both observing the construction rule and calculating the complex numbers, following are an induction process of $z_n$:

$z_{0}$: arbitrary point on the unit circle in the complex plane.

$z_{1}$: By the construction rule $z_1 = \frac{i}{\overline{z_0}}$, lies on the imaginary axis. Notice if $z_0$ is on the right half plane then $z_1$ is on the upper half plane.

$z_2 = \frac{i}{\overline{z_1}}$, lies on the real axis and since $z_1$ is on the upper half plane thus $z_2$ lies on the positive side of the real axis.

$z_3 = \frac{i}{\overline{z_2}}$, lies on the imaginary axis and since $z_2$ is on the right half plane, thus $z_3$ lies on the lower half plane.

And the motion repeats every 4 steps. 

If $z_{2004}$ lies on the positive side of the real axis then $z_0$ lies on the right half plane. 

We get $2004 \bmod 4 = 0$. So $z_{2004} = 1$ and $z_0$ lies on the real axis. We also have $n_{2004} = 501$, but since $n_{2004} \bmod 2 = 0$, 1 should be excluded from the answers. So $z_0$ could be any complex number on the unit circle excluding 1, and this gives us $z_0$ has \[\boxed{360} \text{ possible values}\].
